## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including nice Plots

You can also embed enhanced plots using the `ggplot2` and `ggpubr` packages, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=TRUE}
plot1 <- ggplot(pressure, aes(x=temperature, y=pressure, color=temperature)) +
  geom_point() + geom_line() + scale_color_continuous(low=acufastPink, high=acufastBlue)
plot2 <- ggplot(pressure, aes(x=temperature)) +
  geom_histogram()
plot3 <- ggplot(pressure, aes(x=pressure)) +
  geom_histogram()


ggarrange(plot1,
          ggarrange(plot2,plot3, ncol=2, labels=c("B","C")), 
          nrow=2, labels=c("A",""))
```

Note that the `echo = TRUE` parameter was added to the code chunk to print the R code that generated the table.

## Including nice tables

You can embed formatted tables using the `kableExtra` package, for example:

```{r diamond, echo=TRUE}
kable(head(diamonds), caption="Information about diamonds") %>%
  kable_classic(full_width=F,html_font="Helvetica")
```

Note that the `echo = TRUE` parameter was added to the code chunk to print the R code that generated the table.

## Making columns 

You can make 2 or 3 columns of content using the custom styling functions `<div class="col2">` or `<div class="col3">`.

### As two columns

<div class="col2">

   1) Some things
      + Some sub things
      + Some sub things
   2) Some more things
      + Some more sub things
         - Some sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
   3) Some final things
      + Some final sub things
         - Some final sub sub things
         - Some final sub sub things
         
</div>

### Or as three columns

<div class="col3">

   1) Some things
      + Some sub things
      + Some sub things
   2) Some more things
      + Some more sub things
         - Some sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
         - Some more sub sub things
   3) Some final things
      + Some final sub things
         - Some final sub sub things
         - Some final sub sub things
         
</div>

## Example of Nested Tabs {.tabset .tabset-fade .tabset-pills}

* Below is an example of a Nested Tabset, where the nesting is done in a for() loop. 
  + When using tabs in a for() loop, results = 'asis' needs to be specified
  + Note the use of cat()
* Note the difference in the tab design whether tabset-fade and tabset-pill are used or not 

```{r, echo=FALSE, results='asis'}
my.tabs<-c(1:3)
my.sub.tabs<-c(1,2)

for(i in 1:length(my.tabs)){
  
cat('### Tab',my.tabs[i],' {.tabset} \n')
cat('This is tab ',my.tabs[i],' \n  \n')
for(j in 1:length(my.sub.tabs)){
  cat('#### Sub-Tab',my.sub.tabs[j],' {.tabset} \n')
  cat('This is sub-tab ',my.sub.tabs[j],' \n  \n')
  cat(' \n \n')
}

}
```
